abstract.para: In addition to those applications described in the /etc/shorewall/rules documentation, here are some other services/applications that you may need to configure your firewall to accommodate.

para.emphasis: This article applies to Shorewall 3.0 and later. If you are running a version of Shorewall earlier than Shorewall 3.0.0 then please see the documentation for that release

note.para: In the rules that are shown in this document, the ACTION is shown as ACCEPT. You may need to use DNAT (see FAQ 30) or you may want DROP or REJECT if you are trying to block the application.
Example: You want to port forward FTP from the net to your server at 192.168.1.4 in your DMZ. The FTP section below gives you:
You would code your rule as follows:
note.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DESTINATION PROTO DPORT FTP(DNAT) net dmz:192.168.1.4

section.title: Auth (identd)

para.emphasis: It is now the 21st Century ; don't use identd in production anymore.

section.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DESTINATION PROTO DPORT Auth(ACCEPT) <source> <destination>

section.title: BitTorrent

caution.para: This information is valid only for Shorewall 3.2 or later.

emphasis.emphasis: This rule assumes that your BitTorrent client listens on the default port(s)

section.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DESTINATION PROTO DPORT BitTorrent(ACCEPT)<source> <destination>

section.title: DNS
section.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DESTINATION PROTO DPORT DNS(ACCEPT) <source> <destination>
section.para: Note that if you are setting up a DNS server that supports recursive resolution, the server is the <destination> for resolution requests (from clients) and is also the <source> of recursive resolution requests (usually to other servers in the 'net' zone). So for example, if you have a public DNS server in your DMZ that supports recursive resolution for local clients then you would need:
section.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DESTINATION PROTO DPORT DNS(ACCEPT) all dmz DNS(ACCEPT) dmz net

note.para: Recursive Resolution means that if the server itself can't resolve the name presented to it, the server will attempt to resolve the name with the help of other servers.

section.title: Emule

caution.para: This information is valid only for Shorewall 3.2 or later.

section.para: In contrast to how the rest of this article is organized, for emule I will give you the rules necessary to run emule on a single machine in your loc network (since that's what 99.99% of you want to do). Assume that:

listitem.para: The internal machine running emule has IP address 192.168.1.4.
You use Masquerading or SNAT for the local network.
The zones are named as they are in the two- and three-interface QuickStart guides).

section.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DESTINATION PROTO DPORT Edonkey(DNAT) net loc:192.168.1.4 #if you wish to enable the Emule webserver, add this rule too. DNAT net loc:192.168.1.4 tcp 4711

section.title: FTP
section.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DESTINATION PROTO DPORT FTP(ACCEPT) <source> <destination>
section.para: Look here for much more information.

listitem.para: The internal machine running a Gnutella Client has IP address 192.168.1.4.
You use Masquerading or SNAT for the local network.
The zones are named as they are in the two- and three-interface QuickStart guides).

para.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DESTINATION PROTO DPORT Gnutella(DNAT) net loc:192.168.1.4

section.title: ICQ/AIM
section.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DESTINATION PROTO DPORT ICQ(ACCEPT) <source> net

section.title: IMAP

caution.para: When accessing your mail from the Internet, use only IMAP over SSL.
This information is valid only for Shorewall 3.2 or later.

section.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DESTINATION PROTO DPORT IMAP(ACCEPT) <source> <destination> # Unsecure IMAP IMAPS(ACCEPT) <source> <destination> # IMAP over SSL.

caution.para: This information is valid only for Shorewall 3.2 or later.

caution.para: This information is valid only for Shorewall 3.2 or later.
Allowing access from untrusted hosts to your MySQL server represents a severe security risk.
DO NOT USE THIS if you don't know how to deal with the consequences, you have been warned.

section.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DESTINATION PROTO DPORT MySQL(ACCEPT) <source> <destination>

section.title: NFS
section.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DESTINATION PROTO DPORT ACCEPT <z1>:<list of client IPs> <z2>:a.b.c.d tcp 111 ACCEPT <z1>:<list of client IPs> <z2>:a.b.c.d udp
section.para: For more NFS information, see http://lists.shorewall.net/~kb/.

section.title: Telnet

para.emphasis: The telnet protocol is very insecure, don't use it.

section.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DESTINATION PROTO DPORT Telnet(ACCEPT) <source> <destination>

section.title: TFTP
section.para: You must have TFTP connection tracking support in your kernel. If modularized, the modules are ip_conntrack_tftp (and ip_nat_tftp if any form of NAT is involved) These modules may be loaded using entries in /etc/shorewall/modules. The ip_conntrack_tftp module must be loaded first. Note that the /etc/shorewall/modules file released with recent Shorewall versions contains entries for these modules.
section.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DESTINATION PROTO DPORT ACCEPT <source> <destination> udp 69

section.title: Traceroute
section.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DESTINATION PROTO DPORT Trcrt(ACCEPT) <source> <destination> #Good for 10 hops
section.para: UDP traceroute uses ports 33434 through 33434+<max number of hops>-1. Note that for the firewall to respond with a TTL expired ICMP reply, you will need to allow ICMP 11 outbound from the firewall. The standard Shorewall sample configurations all set this up for you automatically since those sample configurations enable all ICMP packet types originating on the firewall itself.
section.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DESTINATION PROTO DPORT ACCEPT fw net icmp ACCEPT fw loc icmp ACCEPT fw ...

section.title: Usenet (NNTP)
section.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DESTINATION PROTO DPORT NNTP(ACCEPT) <source> <destination> NNTPS(ACCEPT) <source> <destination> # secure NNTP

section.title: VNC

caution.para: This information is valid only for Shorewall 3.2 or later.

section.para: Vncviewer to Vncserver -- TCP port 5900 + <display number>.
the following rule handles VNC traffic for VNC displays 0 - 9.
section.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DESTINATION PROTO DPORT VNC(ACCEPT) <source> <destination>
section.para: Vncserver to Vncviewer in listen mode -- TCP port 5500.
section.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DESTINATION PROTO DPORT VNCL(ACCEPT) <source> <destination>
